studysets.prompt: I would like to learn about common polyatomic ions and their charges, acid-base reactions, and combustion reactions.
studysets.title: Common reactions & ions

question.title: üßæ Charge check
question.author: chem_bites

comments.author: lab_rat_99
comments.content: Wait is nitrate NO3- or NO2-? I'm always mixing them üò≠

comments.author: periodic_pepe
comments.content: Nitrate is NO3- (three oxygens). Nitrite is NO2- ‚Äî literally one less O = different charge vibes.

question.question: Which of the following is the correct charge for sulfate (SO4)?

question.title: üî• Combustion product
question.author: stoich_sam

comments.author: flame_check
comments.content: So complete combustion = CO2 + H2O right? not CO??

comments.author: ash_on_toast
comments.content: Yes for complete. Incomplete gives CO or soot. Context matters lol.

question.question: What are the main products of complete combustion of a hydrocarbon?

question.title: üßÇ Neutralization check
question.author: pH_pal

comments.author: titration_tim
comments.content: Neutralization always gives salt + water, right??

comments.author: acidic_ally
comments.content: Yup, but watch conjugates and spectator ions ‚Äî sometimes reaction looks the same but net ionic is just H+ + OH- -> H2O

question.question: What is the net ionic equation for the neutralization of HCl by NaOH?
choices: H+ + Cl- + Na+ + OH- -> Na+ + Cl- + H2O

question.title: ‚öñÔ∏è Balancing vibe
question.author: balance_queen

comments.author: coeff_master
comments.content: Tip: balance C first, then H, then O. It saves brain cells üôè

comments.author: burn_it_down
comments.content: Also remember oxygen often comes from O2 gas ‚Äî don't forget that 2 in diatomic!

question.question: When burning C3H8 (propane) completely, what is the coefficient in front of O2 in the balanced equation: C3H8 + ? O2 -> 3 CO2 + 4 H2O ?

question.title: üßæ Ion ID trap
question.author: ion_ivy

comments.author: hydro_head
comments.content: Ammonium is NH4+ right? not NH3??

comments.author: chem_mom
comments.content: Correct: NH4+ is ammonium (ion). NH3 is ammonia (neutral). Big difference in reactions.

question.question: What is the charge of the ammonium ion (NH4)?

question.title: üß™ Acid strength quickie
question.author: pKa_pat

comments.author: strong_or_no
comments.content: So HCl is always strong in water but HF is weak, right??

comments.author: solvent_sally
comments.content: HCl strong in water, HF is weak because F- holds onto H tighter. Also solvent matters!

question.question: Which of the following is a strong acid in water?

reels.title: Polyatomic ions speedrun
reels.author: mnemonic_maya

comments.author: shorts_nerd
comments.content: This got me to stop mixing nitrate & nitrite. Thanks lol

comments.author: memory_mic
comments.content: Skateboard cameo lowkey made it iconic üòÇ

reels.video_prompt: Video title: "Polyatomic ions speedrun" ‚Äî Author: mnemonic_maya. Duration 12s. Style: fast-cut, hyperpop, unpredictable humor. Cast: 2 characters (a confident chem-nerd and a dramatic skeptic) plus a skateboarder who zooms through frame at 2s and 8s (not the focus, just cameo). Opening (0-2s): quick neon title splash: "Polyatomic ions ‚Äî 12s cheat". Scene 1 (2-5s): chem-nerd holds flashcards: show SO4¬≤‚Åª (emoji üí•) and says lines: "Sulfate: SO four oxygens, -2 charge ‚Äî think 'SO 4 two'" with a goofy wink. Visual: animated 2‚Åª popping next to formula. Skateboarder rolls by and does a tiny trick, knocks a flashcard that reveals NO3‚Åª. Scene 2 (5-8s): skeptic gasps, chem-nerd: "Nitrate = NO3‚Åª, nitrite = NO2‚Åª (one less O, same mood but less oxygen)" Quick visual: compare NO3‚Åª vs NO2‚Åª with highlight. Scene 3 (8-11s): rapid 3-panel flash of common ions: CO3¬≤‚Åª (carbonate), PO4¬≥‚Åª (phosphate), NH4‚Å∫ (ammonium), OH‚Åª (hydroxide) ‚Äî each with a one-word mnemonic under it (e.g., "CO3: cake (2 layers)" silly). Final beat (11-12s): punchline: skateboarder returns with a giant foam Periodic Table and says offscreen, "Keep the charges, ditch the panic." Quick on-screen text: "Save this üéØ". Speaking outline: short punchy lines only; emphasize charges audibly ("minus two", "plus one"). Visuals: bold colored gradients, emoji overlays, quick formula animations, a tiny particle burst when charges appear. Make it unexpected and funny; skateboard cameo present but not main.

reels.title: Neutralization in 12s (with drama)
reels.author: pH_pixie

comments.author: net_ionic_nate
comments.content: Net ionic explained simply ‚Äî actually useful for labs üî•

comments.author: miss_titration
comments.content: The dramatic gasp was my energy lol

reels.video_prompt: Video title: "Neutralization in 12s (with drama)" ‚Äî Author: pH_pixie. Duration 12s. Style: comedic mini-skit, quick captions, over-the-top acting. Cast: acid (character in red hoodie), base (character in blue cap), plus skateboarder crossing behind the scene at 4s doing a tiny ollie. Opening (0-2s): dramatic close-up on a droplet labeled H+. Scene 1 (2-6s): acid pours a tiny animated H+ into a cup, base throws an OH- like a confetti pop; they do a melodramatic handshake. Voice lines: Acid: "I bring H+", Base: "I got OH-". Scene 2 (6-9s): both gasp as H+ + OH- collide and create H2O ‚Äî show a big water droplet animation and fireworks. Quick caption: "Net ionic: H+ + OH- -> H2O". Scene 3 (9-12s): cut to a table where spectator ions (Na+, Cl-) are chilling on the sidelines with sunglasses labeled 'spectators' ‚Äî a tiny mic drop. End text: "Salt + Water? Yeah. But net ionic = H2O." Speaking outline: emphasize the simplicity: "H plus plus OH equals water"; comedic pause for spectator ions. Visuals: pop-up captions, neon outlines, sudden skateboard cameo, background hyperpop beat.

reels.title: Combustion: balance like a boss
reels.author: stoich_sue

comments.author: oxygen_ollie
comments.content: Propane balancing in 12s? Respect.

comments.author: carbon_claire
comments.content: This made the 'balance C, H, O' order stick better ngl

reels.video_prompt: Video title: "Combustion: balance like a boss" ‚Äî Author: stoich_sue. Duration 12s. Style: energetic rapid-fire tutorial with comedic non-sequiturs. Cast: one chill host, one overexcited assistant, skateboarder zips through at 3s and 9s. Opening (0-2s): text: "Balance combustion in 12s". Scene 1 (2-5s): host writes C3H8 + O2 -> CO2 + H2O. Host: "C first: 3 CO2" ‚Äî big flash of '3'. Scene 2 (5-8s): assistant counts H: "8 H -> 4 H2O" (flash '4'). Scene 3 (8-11s): host solves O: tally O atoms (3*2 + 4*1 = 10) -> O2 coefficient 5. Visuals: tally marks, quick animation converting atoms to oxygen molecules. Final beat (11-12s): assistant throws confetti; text: "C3H8 + 5 O2 -> 3 CO2 + 4 H2O". Speaking outline: narrate steps fast and loud: "C, H, then O ‚Äî boom." Include skateboard cameo for comedic choreography.

comments.author: chem_claire
comments.content: Why is carbonate -2 again? I keep thinking -1 lol

comments.author: memorize_me
comments.content: Pro tip: learn a handful (SO4¬≤‚Åª, NO3‚Åª, CO3¬≤‚Åª, PO4¬≥‚Åª, OH‚Åª, NH4‚Å∫) and you cover like 80% of problems

comments.author: panic_at_lab
comments.content: This actually helped me on the quiz fr

slides.content: SO4¬≤‚Åª sulfate ‚Äî charge -2
NO3‚Åª nitrate ‚Äî charge -1 (NO2‚Åª is nitrite: -1 with one less O)
CO3¬≤‚Åª carbonate ‚Äî -2; PO4¬≥‚Åª phosphate ‚Äî -3
OH‚Åª hydroxide ‚Äî -1; NH4‚Å∫ ammonium ‚Äî +1
Most polyatomic oxyanions have negative charges; memorize families, not every weird one

comments.author: sulfix
comments.content: Sulfite vs sulfate always trips me up. Appreciate the side-by-side!

comments.author: oxide_kid
comments.content: Remember -ite = one less oxygen than -ate

slides.content: Sulfate: SO4¬≤‚Åª (common in salts like Na2SO4)
Sulfite: SO3¬≤‚Åª (same -2 charge but one less O)
Tip: -ate usually has more oxygens than -ite

comments.author: confused_cory
comments.content: I always forget which has 3 O's ‚Äî this stuck

comments.author: nitro_nick
comments.content: Nitrate = NO3‚Åª, nitrite = NO2‚Åª. memorize that tiny difference = huge consequences

slides.content: Nitrate: NO3‚Åª (common in fertilizers)
Nitrite: NO2‚Åª (one less oxygen; watch reactivity)
Both usually carry -1 charge in salts

comments.author: ammonia_amy
comments.content: NH4+ vs NH3 saved my lab day ‚Äî thanks!!

comments.author: oh_snap
comments.content: OH- is basic, NH4+ is acidic-ish when donating H+ (as conjugate acid of NH3)

slides.content: OH‚Åª = hydroxide, common strong base component
NH4‚Å∫ = ammonium, conjugate acid of NH3, charge +1
NH3 is neutral gas; NH4+ is the ion ‚Äî different behavior in solution

comments.author: philosophy_phil
comments.content: So acids donate H+, bases accept H+ ‚Äî simple but gets messy with conjugates

comments.author: titr8er
comments.content: This is the one I actually use in solving problems

slides.content: Acid: proton (H+) donor
Base: proton (H+) acceptor
Conjugate acid/base pairs: HA <-> H+ + A-

posts.title: Strong vs weak acids ‚Äî real talk
posts.author: pKa_pal

comments.author: weakling
comments.content: So strong = fully dissociate in water? that seems binary but ok

comments.author: chem_cliff
comments.content: Yep. HCl, HBr, HI, HNO3, H2SO4 (first H) are common strong acids

slides.content: Strong acids: almost complete dissociation in water (e.g., HCl, HNO3)
Weak acids: partial dissociation (e.g., CH3COOH, HF). Use Ka or pH to quantify
If a problem says 'strong acid', treat it as full H+ source

comments.author: sooty_sam
comments.content: I forgot CO is a product of incomplete ‚Äî almost died in chem lab lol

comments.author: safety_sue
comments.content: CO is toxic and colorless ‚Äî know the difference for real-world contexts

slides.content: Complete combustion of hydrocarbon -> CO2 + H2O
Incomplete combustion -> CO, C (soot), sometimes H2O + less CO2
O2 availability controls completeness ‚Äî limited O2 = incomplete

comments.author: panic_balancer
comments.content: That C,H,O order saved my exam ngl

comments.author: half_done
comments.content: Just remember to multiply H2O count √ó1 for O total ‚Äî saved me mistakes

slides.content: Step 1: Balance C ‚Äî set coefficient of CO2 = # of C in fuel
Step 2: Balance H ‚Äî set coefficient of H2O = (# H in fuel)/2
Step 3: Balance O ‚Äî count total O on product side, divide by 2 for O2
If O2 coefficient is fractional, multiply whole equation to clear fractions
